811066.gauge_pattern: 5 3/4" long and 2 7/8" wide after completing Rnd 3
811066.name: Crocheted Midwifery Scale Sling
811066.gauge_description: 5 3/4" long and 2 7/8" wide after completing Rnd 3
811066.notes_html:
PDF pattern, now updated with photos for additional help, to make a basket-style infant sling. Perfect for use with handheld, hanging scales to measure birth weight or to perform weight checks at home. Also beautiful as a newborn photography prop.

I created this pattern after Farm midwife Stacie Hunt sent me a picture of a baby in a crocheted scale sling and asked if I could make something like it. A bit of thinking, a lot of frogging, and a few test slings later, and I think I came up with something that we’re both happy with.

If made to specified gauge, approximate unstretched dimensions: 8” deep x 15” long. Shown with a 7 lb baby.

Please use your finished item responsibly. Not for sleeping. Do not leave infant in sling unattended. Always use over a stable, padded surface.

I consider this pattern to be advanced beginner level. Helpful skills to have are working on both sides of a foundation chain, working in continuous rounds, and finishing off with a needle join. Please don’t hesitate to ask if you need help!

This pattern may not be redistributed, copied, or altered in any way or used for commercial production. You may sell finished items, but please list Southern Hands as the pattern author and include our Etsy store address: tinyurl.com/SouthernHandsShop

824436.name: Knitty Titty
824436.sizes_available: Bra cup sizes A (B, C, D)
824436.gauge_description: 22 stitches and 28 rows = 4 inches in stockinette stitch
824436.notes_html:
Knitty Titty

This is a quick knit, comfy, soft, light breast prosthesis that is knitted from the center to the front and then center to back, with no “pick up and knits” or seaming needed. I’m not a fast knitter but I can make one of these, including the stuffing, in under two hours.

I wrote this pattern because other patterns require starting with just a few stitches of lighter weight yarn on each of three double-pointed needles and I have trouble with that. Also, they all required more stitches with thinner yarn and a lot of increases which slowed down the knitting.

By beginning in the middle, this pattern avoids the fiddly difficulty of beginning with just a few stitches on each needle. Also, k2tog’s replace the increases used in other patterns, which simplifies and speeds up the knitting process.

Instructions are given for double-pointed needles, but I also provide a note on how to adapt the pattern to two circulars.

Pattern is written for approximate bra sizes A (B, C, D) but sizes can be easily adjusted by beginning with more or less stitches on each needle and continuing with the same knitting process.

I suggest using a light, worsted weight yarn in a soft cotton blend but, again, this pattern can be easily adapted to the yarn of your choice.

825548.name: Bust Buddies
825548.gauge_description: 22 stitches and 32 rows = 4 inches in stockinette stitch
825548.notes_html:
This is a FREE pattern.

Sitting one evening, wanting to start another pair of Softies, a knitted breast prosthetic that I designed, I began to wonder about other ways to engineer this pattern for an easier way to start. I enjoy working dpn needles but feel free to substitute two circular needles or the magic loop needle.

So what did I do? I turned my Softies on its head and called them Bust Buddies! These start at the center of the bottom, increase to the desired number of stitches, and then decreased down to 9 stitches. This easily memorized pattern is THE knitting project I take to meetings with a personal goal of knitting (at least) one pair per month. I donate them to hospitals, breast cancer runs and walks, and to breast cancer survivor events. Women love wearing them.

Bust Buddies begin with 19 stitches – no more fiddling with a few stitches – and then I use my clever way to connect these stitches into a circular approach which is the same way I connect the cast on for cuff-down socks that I think is perfect. Lots of words for an easy task – read it through a few times and then check out the pictures in the pattern.

Also check out some Stitch Marker Magic!

The back story: my mother-in-law struggled with the challenges of finding clothing to fit comfortably after a radical mastectomy back in the late 1960’s. I was knitting but never thought about knitting something as important as making her feel like the beautiful woman she was, and she would have loved these! Softies, and now Bust Buddies, are in honor of my dear mother–in-law, Anne Adler.

Bust Buddies: http://sandiegoknitters.com/philanthropy/softies/

users.about_me:
As a little girl I dreamed about the day when I would become a member of “the knitting group” but first I had to learn how to knit!  On a summer afternoon, my mother demonstrated a few stitches, watched the laborious execution of a few, and with her encouragement, I learned to knit; I was probably six years old.  Over time, I orchestrated a knitting life that encompasses designing, teaching, and writing.  Knitting is my constant companion because within my hands and within my heart I hold the unequivocal gratitude for my mother’s patience and insight, and for the many others who continue to enrich my journey every day.

Knitting has become even more important as I continue my journey as a courageous care partner. Please support "Courageous Care Partners" by signing up for my website: https://eileenadler.com/contact

My blog includes helpful hints and Self-care Rituals and can be found at
https://eileenadler.com/blog

"Courageous Care Partners," my book, includes stories about women who should not have succeeded given the obstacles they faced but they did. Each imparts a Life Lesson and a Self-care Ritual to inspire us. The book features easy-to-fix recipes, poems, knitting patterns, vignettes, and inspiring stories. My journey began many years ago and the information included sustains me. My hope is that you will find support as well.

https://eileenadler.com

Thank you.

828005.name: Boo-Boo Bunny Knit Pouch
828005.notes_html:
As spring rolls around kids are starting to play outside. The more kids are outside and playing together the more times they will get boo boos. It was always a struggle for me to get my kids to use an ice pack because it was “too cold”. Now, with the boo boo bunny you can reduce swelling with something your kids will want to use. Boo Boo tested, bunny approved.

This pattern is available for free on my blog here.

Or you can purchase the Ad-Free PDF!

Materials:
1 ball Scrubby Smoothie in Loofah
Scraps of Scrubby Cotton in Blushing Print and Caribbean
14″ US size 8 knitting needles
Yarn needle
Scissors
2 stitch markers

865397.name: Breast Forms
865397.sizes_available: Breast cup sizes A, B, C, D & DD/E, DDD/F, G, H, I, J
865397.notes_html:
These breasts could be used as novelty items however when I made the pattern it was meant for those who’ve had to undergo mastectomies and were in need of a prosthesis. These breasts are flat on the back so will sit comfortably against the chest while inside the bra. Breasts are stuffed with FiberFil and are constructed in such a way that the stuffing can easily be removed/restuffed so you can launder the breasts. ((Machine wash/lay flat to dry. I highly recommend the use of a garment bag to launder items in)).

Pattern includes breast cup sizes A, B, C, D & DD/E, DDD/F, G, H, I, and J. Please keep in mind when making these that breast cup sizes are all relative… there is not a “one cup size fits all’.

Pattern uses Lion Brand 24/7 (worsted weight 4 cotton yarn) OR Caron Simply Soft (worsted weight 4 acrylic yarn) and includes step-by-step instructions (and photos where needed). Written in US/American terms.

You will need Adobe Reader to open this pattern. The program can be downloaded for Free at http://www.adobe.com

♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥
Once your payment has cleared, you will receive an email with all the information needed to download your file. The process can take several minutes, please be patient. If you have any problems, please contact me.

865422.name: Breast Cancer Awareness Boobies
865422.notes_html:
FREE CROCHET PATTERN

These Breast Cancer Awareness Boobies is part of the Breast Cancer Awareness initiative.  These Boobies are designed especially for women who have undergone mastectomies and need a breast prosthetic - this is very near and dear to me as I lost a granny from this terrible disease - 1 in 27 South African women suffer from breast cancer and many do not have money to have professional prosthetic’s or breast implants done, so this is my way of giving back.

These Boobies are designed especially for women who have undergone mastectomies and need breast prosthetic’s.  They are soft and light, comfortable to wear, the 100% natural yarn and stuffing allows the skin to breath and they are easy to wash, and cheap to replace.  They can be placed in a regular bra.

My pattern provides the instructions to make 3 different size Boobies - A/B cup, C/D cup and DD/E cup.

This is a free pattern which I designed in September 2018, after a friend suggested that I do one.  October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month in South Africa - make a set and donate to your local charity, or for a friend 

Pattern Discounts

Coupon code: 15OFF Purchase any 2 patterns and get 15% discount

users.about_me:
I am a crochet designer and fiber artist, yarn snob, coffee, red wine & chocolate addict, wife, sister, daughter and mom to four.

And I crochet…did I mention that?

Ok, so if I am being honest, I crochet a lot.

I have not been crocheting for long, but the first time I picked up a hook, some yarn, and a pattern to make a baby blanket for charity, I was, as they say, hooked.

​When my little girl told me that she felt snuggled in my love when lying under a blankets I had made her, it occurred to me that she was right.

​When we make something for someone else, we pour our love, passion and creativity into it.

As you know creative people need to have time to be creative.  Crocheting is my passion, and is “like painting with yarn”. I love to play with patterns and colours, and create something unique and beautiful for people I love, and I am sure you do too.

My patterns are easy to read, with loads of clear photos, helpful hints along the way, a print friendly and a photo tutorial, and all my Melly Teddy Ragdolls come with unique birth certificates.

So, happy crocheting 
Hugs xx
Melanie

PS : 'share the art within you with the ones you love'
AND
PPS: 'let's paint with yarn"

I have not been crocheting for long, but the first time I picked up a hook, some yarn, and a pattern to make a baby blanket for charity, I was, as they say, hooked.

​When my little girl told me that she felt snuggled in my love when lying under a blankets I had made her, it occurred to me that she was right.

​When we make something for someone else, we pour our love, passion and creativity into it.

As you know creative people need to have time to be creative. Crocheting is my passion, and is “like painting with yarn”. I love to play with patterns and colours, and create something unique and beautiful for people I love, and I am sure you do too.

My patterns are easy to read, with loads of clear photos, helpful hints along the way, a print friendly and a photo tutorial, and all my Melly Teddy Ragdolls come with unique birth certificates.

So, happy crocheting
Hugs xx
Melanie

PS : ‘share the art within you with the ones you love’
AND
PPS: ‘let’s paint with yarn“

886240.name: PibCo
886240.notes_html:
I just added a short English version. Just the basic stitch information. Please use Stitch Maps link. Make sure to expand “description” for details and “written instructions” for a stitch by stitch description of the cast on and the main section.

PibCo: Pibella Cozy
Pibella: a female urination device. You can use it wherever you do not find a clean rest room.

Wer jemals unterwegs irgendwo auf eine Toilette geht und nie ein ekliges Etwas vorfindet, hat wahrscheinlich unverschämtes Glück. Und wer nun mit den nicht so hübschen Toiletten konfrontiert ist, wird bei der Suche nach Gegenmaßnahmen auch auf Urinierhilfen für Frauen stoßen. Ich nenne eine Pibella mein eigen und sie ist meist dabei, wenn ich unterwegs bin.

Für die Pibella nutze ich diese Hülle aus Baumwollgarn. Recht fest gestrickt. So ist die Pibella unterwegs gut untergebracht. Und die Hülle ist auch so neutral, dass nicht jeder gleich erkennen würde, was ich da rumtrage.

In den seltenen Fällen, wo sie wirklich benutzt wird, stellt die Hülle nur sicher, dass evtl. noch vorhandene minimale Mengen an Flüssigkeit aufgesogen werden. Wer mag, kann das dann auch noch in eine Plastiktüte stecken. Zuhause geht die Hülle in diesem Fall dann sowieso in die Wäsche. Da ist also gar nicht so arg viel Zeit, in der es zu Gerüchen kommen könnte.

pattern_author.name: Silke R
pattern_author.notes:
.

My designs: I don’t feel like a designer. But I use to write down some of my ideas. Once written down I share those ideas here in Ravelry. If you expect a perfect pattern please do not download my patterns. If you are willing to give my patterns a try I will always provide support if needed.

Many of my pattern have some experimental aspects: a tricky part, ideas for different usage, variations... I like that. If you consider that confusing be aware. 

If you plan to work my designs for charity purposes go ahead. I am happy if I can contribute.

I guess you realized that English is not my first language. I would highly appreciate any proposal to improve my wording. Same for notifications on any errors. My patterns are not being tested in advance. 

**DEUTSCH**
======
Meine Designs: Na, ja, ich bin keine Designerin. Aber ich schreibe mir immer etwas auf, wenn ich was stricke. Und manchmal bereite ich das dann soweit auf, dass ich meine Ideen hier in Ravelry auch anderen zur Verfügung stellen kann. Wenn du perfekte Anleitungen suchst, lad sie lieber nicht runter. Aber wenn du etwas von mir versuchen willst, werde ich mich gern bemühen, deine Fragen bei Bedarf zu beantwortet.

Oft enthalten meine Anleitungen einen "experimentellen Teil". Eine kniffelige Stelle, eine komische Masche, einen Vorschlag um etwas abzuwandeln, Varianten etc. Ich mag sowas, aber manche empfinden das als verwirrend. Daher warne ich hier vorsorglich. 

Falls du meine Anleitungen für soziale Projekte nacharbeiten willst: sehr gerne. Und noch lieber, wenn du ein Projekt mit Bild dazu anlegst.

Über Verbesserungsvorschläge und Hinweise zu Fehlern bin ich froh. Ich bin halt nur ein handarbeitender Mensch und meine Anleitungen durchlaufen keinen Testprozess.

951015.name: Alternative ML Knitted Knockers
951015.notes_html:
The ‘Knitted Knockers’ web site has a (free) pattern for Magic Loop knockers, but I found it a little bit cumbersome.

This pattern is just a variation of the original patter that makes knitting the knockers Magic Loop-style, and 2-at-a-time, a little bit easier.

This is achieved by having not 3, but 6 increase points, and therefore balancing the stitches on the needles without re-distributing the stitches, which is quite awkward when knitting 2-at-a-time.

On the back side there are also 6 decrease points, which makes the decreases less of a ridge, and therefore softer.

Direct link to the .pdf

(Raveler #327692)

**About my stash: **

I love all my yarns; some will not be leaving my cold, dead hands. But if I have a yarn that you desperately need, let me know.

I reserve the right to say ‘No’, but my knitting bacon has been saved a couple of times by people who generously and kindly gave up some of their stash to help me.

Therefore, I am inclined to pay back.

----------------------------------------------
Stranded Knitting Know-How

[Continental Stranded Knitting][1]
[Zweifarbig mit Elizza][2]
[Roxanne: Colorwork][3]
[Nimble Needles Colorwork][4]
[Fadenhaltung][5]
[Kontrastfaden einstricken][6]

[Ein Koffer voll Wolle (Stopfen und Anderes)][7]
-------------------------------------------------
[Interesting way to join, unfortunately only on instagram][8]

**Description:**

*natalya1905's profile picture
:hearts: HOW I KNIT: JOIN NEW YARN :hearts:
Today I'd like to show you how I join new yarn. Why is this method so good?*
- *It's secure (weave in ends afterwards as you normally would)*
- *No double strands of yarn.*
- *No knots.* 
*For clarity and your convenience, I picked two different yarn colors.* 

This video is pretty self-explanatory, but I'll give you the written steps, just in case.

1. Knit to the stitch where you need to
   join new yarn.
2. Get new yarn (a new color or a new
   skein). Cross ends as shown in the
   video.
3. Knit 3-5 stitches, picking
   alternating strands of  "old" yarn.
4. Knit 3-5 stitches, picking
   alternating strands of  "new" yarn.
5. Continue to knit as normal with new
   yarn.

 Voila!
*:hearts: I hope you enjoy. Your likes, comments, saves and shares are much appreciated. Thank you!*

--- copied from Natalya1905's instagram because not on YouTube, so I can't link ----

-----------------------------------------------------

Net Stitch:
[The Knitting Novice Blog; Clarice Asquith:][9]

**Net Knit Stitch or Filet Net Knit Stitch**
(Requires a multiple of 3 stitches.)

**Row 1** (right side): K2, \*sl 2, pass 1st slipped stitch over 2nd and off the needle, sl1, pass 2nd slipped stitch over 3rd and off the needle, slip 3rd slipped stitch back onto left-hand needle, yo x2 (making two sts), knit 3rd slipped stitch; rep from \* to last stitch, k1.  (The number of cast-on stitches remains the same.)

**Row 2**: K3, \*p1, k2; rep from \* to end of row. 

Repeat Rows 1 and 2. 

-----------------------------
I will have to try this, but it looks freakingly fabulous!

  

August  3, 2023
===================================
Other 'Net/Mesh' pattern
[Here][10]
Not as nice and light and elegant, but perhaps for different application.



---------------------------------------------------

Beautiful Edges:

[Video here][11]

Description:
You need to add 2 stitches from your pattern, one for right edge, one for left edge.
Prep. row: slip purlwise with yarn in front, yo, your pattern, k1. 
THE ROW: slip purlwise with yarn in front, yo, your pattern, k2tog the yo & slip stitches. Repeat this row. 


  

June  3, 2023
===================================
Also, video demonstrating on [how to knit 1/1 ribbing][12]

June 21, 2023
===================================
Also, [Distitch Selvage][13]
[Assia Brill HR Cables][14]
[Super Cables HR cables][15] (10 stitches a day)

May 2024
=============
Neat SSK Patty Lyons: [youtube][16]


  [1]: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bpffgVthxgk&ab_channel=KristinLehrer
  [2]: https://www.nadelspiel.com/2012/06/07/zweifarbig-stricken-a-la-elizzza-die-fair-isle-stricken-revolution/
  [3]: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL1AZxTfSCe2ciu_XbYOVClammwvqVzIiy
  [4]: https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=nimble+needles+colorwork

  [7]: https://www.youtube.com/@Ein_Koffer_Voll_Wolle
  [8]: https://www.instagram.com/natalya1905/reel/CsJcZxjMeNy/
  [9]: https://makedoandmendnovice.blogspot.com/2019/09/the-weekly-swatch-net-knit-stitch-or.html?m=1
  [10]: https://knit-charts.com/knitting-stitch-patterns/item/mesh-stitch-knitting-pattern-3.html
  [11]: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wjBd1sHb4QI&ab_channel=KnittedIdeas

C. 1896

It is made of two knitted pieces, sewn together on all sides but one. Mentholated ointment is applied to a piece of cloth, which is tucked inside. Elastic loops are sewn to the ends which go over the ears.

The pattern calls for black yarn on one side and white yarn on the other.

The pattern is on page 137 of the book.

973548.name: No-Sew Heat Packs
973548.notes_html:
Heat packs can alleviate pain from arthritis, ear aches, cramps, sore muscles, and more. When I need an emergency heat pack, I fill a tube sock with rice, and microwave it. It’s a perfect, quick solution for some relief- aside from one thing. It’s ugly! So I made a cute cover that can hide the simple, no sew upcycle of a tube sock into a comfy heat pack.

This pattern includes lots of instructions for whatever kind of cover and pack you want to make. The covers are available in two sizes:

The Large Cover holds two heat packs, and is about ten inches wide and ten inches long.

The Small Covers hold one heat pack each, and 245 yards is plenty enough yarn to make two. This size is about 5 inches wide and ten inches long.

There are three ways to make the heat packs, including the no sew option, a one-seam option, and a fully sewn fabric option.

Additional supplies for this projects include:

  • Size H Hook
  • Size G Hook
  • Two tube socks (or a fat quarter of fabric with matching thread)
  • 2-3 cups of dry rice per heat pack

Optional supplies:

  • Two matching buttons
  • Thread

I love these covers because they protect your skin from the full heat of the rice packs, and they keep the rice hot for more time.

Gauge is not important for this pattern. Heavier weight yarn can be used, although it will block even more of the heat from getting through the heat pack. I find DK weight yarn to be the best suited for this.

Some photos are included in the pattern.

Lastly, the texture and design of the covers is meant to appeal specifically to hand dyed yarn. The covers only need about 100 grams of yarn (approx 245 yards), and the texture is meant to compliment the color changes that often come with hand dyed yarn. Perfect for if you only have one skein of your favorite yarn!

Give the finished product as a gift during the cold winter months, or give this pattern as a gift alongside some beautiful hand dyed dk yarn!

Still not sure what to do with your most special hank of yarn? Check out my store for more designs you can make with only 100 grams!
973548.notes:
Heat packs can alleviate pain from arthritis, ear aches, cramps, sore muscles, and more. When I need an emergency heat pack, I fill a tube sock with rice, and microwave it. It's a perfect, quick solution for some relief- aside from one thing. It's ugly! So I made a cute cover that can hide the simple, no sew upcycle of a tube sock into a comfy heat pack. 

This pattern includes lots of instructions for whatever kind of cover and pack you want to make. The covers are available in two sizes:

The Large Cover holds two heat packs, and is about ten inches wide and ten inches long. 

The Small Covers hold one heat pack each, and 245 yards is plenty enough yarn to make two. This size is about 5 inches wide and ten inches long. 

There are three ways to make the heat packs, including the no sew option, a one-seam option, and a fully sewn fabric option. 

Additional supplies for this projects include:

- Size H Hook
- Size G Hook
- Two tube socks (or a fat quarter of fabric with matching thread)
- 2-3 cups of dry rice per heat pack

Optional supplies:

- Two matching buttons
- Thread

I love these covers because they protect your skin from the full heat of the rice packs, and they keep the rice hot for more time. 

Gauge is not important for this pattern. Heavier weight yarn can be used, although it will block even more of the heat from getting through the heat pack. I find DK weight yarn to be the best suited for this. 

Some photos are included in the pattern.

Lastly, the texture and design of the covers is meant to appeal specifically to hand dyed yarn. The covers only need about 100 grams of yarn (approx 245 yards), and the texture is meant to compliment the color changes that often come with hand dyed yarn.  Perfect for if you only have one skein of your favorite yarn!

Give the finished product as a gift during the cold winter months, or give this pattern as a gift alongside some beautiful hand dyed dk yarn!

Still not sure what to do with your most special hank of yarn? Check out my store for more designs you can make with only 100 grams!

991713.name: Arm Cast Sleeve
991713.gauge_description: 18 stitches and 26 rows = 4 inches in stockinette stitch
991713.notes_html:
A simple cover for your casted fellow, this sleeve knits up like a fingerless mitten. It functions to keep the cast protected from wear and tear and mild precipitation. It is washable and offers a softer texture than the rough cast material underneath. Designed with the user in mind, the sleeve is easy to put on and take off yet fits close to the cast.

1006307.name: Snazzy Crutch Covers
1006307.sizes_available: One size fits standard underarm/axillary crutches
1006307.gauge_description: 8 stitches and 12 rows = 4 inches in brioche rib stitch
1006307.notes_html:
JOIN THE SNAZZY CRUTCH CLUB!

Being on crutches for any length of time can be a bit of a downer. So, why not brighten up your new friends with some accessories of their own?

I designed these to mix and match & use up scrap yarn for a super quick, fun, AND functional project. The little stretch of garter stitch at the top of the covers provides a nice bit of cushion for the underarms, and they’re also stretchy enough to fit over extra padding should you need it.

But more importantly for me at least, they were a huge mood booster during recovery and made me feel super snazzy :)

Skill Level:
Advanced Beginner (cover is primarily made up of 2 color brioche rib stitch)

Yarn:
Any bulky weight yarn in 3 colors; I used worsted weight held double to achieve a bulky weight | approx 73 yd (for 1 cover) or 146 yd (for 2 covers) -- Yardage total is for 1 strand of bulky weight yarn; if using multiple strands, total is approx per 1 strand

Per 1 crutch cover:
C1 - 17 yd / 15 m (base ribbing)
C2 - 28 yd / 25 m (brioche knit stitches)
C3 - 28 yd / 25 m (brioche purl stitches)

Shown:
Various colors of Red Heart Super Saver

Needles:
US size 10.5 (6.5mm) 16” circular needle or size needed to obtain gauge

Size:
One size fits standard underarm/axillary crutches

1053583.name: Breast Prosthetic Round
1053583.notes_html:
I used the Universal X Sock Loom in the 1/4” gauge loom. If Cindwood puts out a hat loom in that gauge you can make a size D and up cup size.
This is not an approved Knitted Knockers pattern but can be donated to your local hospital or can be made for a friend on family.
This version is done in the round which should be easier to make than the flat version.
It has a full video tutorial and is an intermediate pattern with increases and decreases in the middle of the garment.
I used Lions Brand Coboo but you could probably make 2 breasts with one cake.

1058062.name: Crochet Boob
1058062.notes_html:
The mighty crochet boob is a perfect, quick make for any occasion! Use it for teaching breastfeeding techniques, make it to celebrate your breastfeeding milestones or gift to a supportive friend or midwife.
The crochet boob is easy to customise as it comes in 3 sizes and also 3 nipple and areola sizes, making it a total of 9 boobiful combinations!
